dy.title: Dividend Yield
dy.desc: The unit of Price and Dividend needs to be the same (dollar/cent)

pe.title: PE Ratio
pe.desc: The unit of P/E and EPS needs to be the same (dollar/cent)

peg.title: Zulu Principle (PEG ≤ 1.0)
peg.desc: Check if PEG ratio meets Zulu Principle (PEG ≤ 1.0)

peDiscount.title: Historical PE Discount
peDiscount.desc: Compare current PE to historical average for safety margin

sleepStrategyGate.name: Sleep Strategy Gate
sleepStrategyGate.description: Review these qualitative factors (recommended). You may proceed even if not all criteria are met.

quantitativeEntry.name: Quantitative Data Entry
quantitativeEntry.description: Input key financial metrics. If the data is available in your log book, you can auto-fill it here.

valueChain.label: Value Chain
valueChain.description: Does the company have stable needs → Revenue → Profit flow?

dividendPolicy.label: Dividend Policy
dividendPolicy.description: Is there a consistent history of paying dividends?

management.label: Management Integrity
management.description: Is the management honest? (No accounting scandals)

moat.label: Competitive Moat
moat.description: Does the company have a clear competitive advantage?

coldEye.title: The Cold Eye Philosophy
coldEye.intro: The "Cold Eye" approach emphasizes disciplined, emotionless investing based on fundamental analysis. Instead of following market hype or emotional decisions, investors should evaluate companies using quantitative metrics.

gdpScore.title: GDP Score
gdpScore.desc: Measures wealth creation through Growth (CAGR), Dividends, and Price (PE ratio)

prcScore.title: PRC Score
prcScore.desc: Measures wealth sustainability through Profit margin, ROE, and Cash flow

threshold.title: Score > 100
threshold.desc: Minimum threshold for investment consideration (Grade A)

sleepStrategy.title: The Sleep Strategy
sleepStrategy.intro: Before analyzing any numbers, ask yourself: "Can I sleep well at night owning this stock?" This requires passing the qualitative gate:

opportunityCost.title: Opportunity Cost
opportunityCost.desc: Every investment decision has an opportunity cost. By investing in one stock, you forgo the returns of others. The Cold Eye method ensures you only invest in companies that meet high standards, reducing the chance of poor allocation.

cagr.description: Measures the average annual growth rate of an investment over a specified period, smoothing out volatility.

peRatio.description: Shows how much investors are willing to pay for each dollar of earnings. Lower is generally better.

pegRatio.description: Adjusts PE for growth. A PEG ≤ 1.0 suggests the stock may be undervalued relative to its growth rate (Zulu Principle).

dividendYield.description: The percentage return from dividends alone. Higher yields indicate better income potential.

netProfitMargin.description: Shows how much profit a company keeps from each dollar of revenue. Higher margins indicate better efficiency.

roe.description: Measures how effectively a company uses shareholder capital to generate profits.

psRatio.description: Useful for companies with low or negative earnings. Must be combined with profit margin analysis.

findingData.title: Finding Financial Data
findingData.intro: To use this analyzer effectively, you need access to company financial statements. Here's where to find them:

annualReports.title: Annual Reports
annualReports.desc: Visit the company's Investor Relations page. Key sections:
annualReports.incomeStatement: Income Statement: Net profit, revenue, EPS

1.title: Pass the Qualitative Gate
1.desc: Verify the company meets all 4 criteria before proceeding

2.title: Calculate 5-Year CAGR
2.desc: Compare net profit from 5 years ago to today

7.title: Assess Cash Flow
7.desc: Is the company profitable? Is cash flow positive?

8.title: Review Your Score
8.desc: Total should exceed 100 for Grade A

tips.calculator: Use the Toolbox calculators for quick checks
tips.compare: Compare multiple companies in the same sector
tips.trends: Look at 5-10 year trends, not just current values
tips.zulu: Use the Zulu Principle to filter growth stocks
tips.discount: Check Historical PE Discount for value opportunities

techGrowth.title: Unfriendly to Tech & Growth Stocks
techGrowth.intro: The current model may penalize high-growth companies unjustly:

dividendIssues.title: Dividend Issues
dividendIssues.desc: Great tech companies (like early Amazon or Tesla) often reinvest profits instead of paying dividends, leading to low scores.

peIssues.title: PE Ratio Issues
peIssues.desc: Quality growth stocks often trade at PE > 30x. This model would give them only 5 points.

techGrowth.result: Result: You might miss an entire tech bull run and end up only with traditional sectors like Banks, Real Estate, or Manufacturing.

laggingIndicators.title: Lagging Indicators
laggingIndicators.desc: Compounded Growth (CAGR) and ROE depend on past data. A perfect past score doesn't guarantee future success if an industry is facing disruption (e.g., film cameras vs. digital). This model cannot evaluate future business models.

simplifiedCashFlow.title: Simplified Cash Flow
simplifiedCashFlow.desc: The model gives 40 points for "Profit + Net Inflow". However, expanding companies may have negative cash flow due to heavy investment (R&D, factories). This isn't necessarily bad; it could be the calm before the explosion.

suitableFor.title: Suitable For
items: Investors who don't want to watch the market daily
Identifying Blue Chips or Second-liners in traditional markets (e.g., Bursa Malaysia)

source.title: Source: "The Ultimate Stock Market Solution"
source.desc: Core Philosophy: Value Investing, Defense & Offense. Growth as primary, Value as secondary.
